qas.question: What are variations on Dutch used in Belgium sometimes called?
What is the Dutch language officially called in the Netherlands?
What would someone in Belgium call the variation of Dutch spoken in Flanders?
What is the Dutch name for the "Hollandish" dialect of the language?
If "Vlaams" is "Flemish," what would English speakers call "West-Vlaams"?

context: While Dutch generally refers to the language as a whole, Belgian varieties are sometimes collectively referred to as <a0_0>Flemish<a0_0/>. In both Belgium and the Netherlands, the native official name for Dutch is <a1_0>Nederlands<a1_0/>, and its dialects have their own names, e.g. <a3_0>Hollands<a3_0/> "Hollandish", West-Vlaams "<a4_0>Western Flemish<a4_0/>", Brabants "Brabantian". The use of the word <a2_0>Vlaams<a2_0/> ("Flemish") to describe Standard Dutch for the variations prevalent in Flanders and used there, however, is common in the Netherlands and Belgium.
